document.docTitle: Benthic community patterns and the composition of feeding types and reproductive modes in freshwater nematodes

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Benthic community patterns and the composition of feeding types and reproductive modes in freshwater nematodes

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Department for Animal Ecology, University Bielefeld, Morgenbreede 45, 33615 Bielefeld, Germany
Department for Animal Ecology, University Bielefeld, Morgenbreede 45, 33615 Bielefeld, Germany

emphasis.docTitle: Benthic community patterns and the composition of feeding types and reproductive modes in freshwater nematodes

subSection.paragraph: Iris C. MICHIELS ∗ and Walter TRAUNSPURGER

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Department for Animal Ecology, University Bielefeld, Morgenbreede 45, 33615 Bielefeld, Germany

subSection.paragraph: Received: 4 October 2004; revised: 17 November 2004
Accepted for publication: 19 November 2004

Summary – We characterised benthic invertebrate community composition in 11 oligotrophic, alpine lakes. Nematodes were the most abundant benthic taxa in most lakes but community composition differed markedly. Several relationships between the invertebrate taxa were found but there was no strong evidence that competition or predation shaped the benthic community structure. Most lakes were dominated by a few nematode species with cosmopolitan distribution. Obligate and/or facultative parthenogenetic species were most abundant. With increasing species richness, the overall sex-ratio increased and the relative abundance of parthenogenetic species decreased.
Keywords – abundance, alpine lakes, biodiversity, biomass, sex-ratio, trophic composition, zoobenthos.

Freshwater benthic organisms are abundant and diverse. They regulate major ecosystem processes ( Bardgett, 2002 ) and play an important ecological role in detrital food webs (
Eyualem et al. , 2001
; Schmid & Schmid-Araya, 2002). However, there is still a debate as to what are the mechanisms determining benthos community structure.
Strayer et al. (1997)
showed that abiotic factors (oxygen, sediment granulometry, resources) are important in determining the distribution of animals. In contrast,
Silver et al. (2002)
suggested that primary productivity and the availability and quality of organic matter influence benthic invertebrate community composition. In benthic communities, the high species richness leads to a large number of biotic interactions and trophic links ( Pimm, 1980 ; Schmid & Schmid-Araya, 2002). Studies on the effect of biotic factors, such as competition and predation, are controversial. In lotic habitats, there is little evidence that competition between benthic invertebrates influences the overall distribution patterns; however, it may play a role for some taxa ( Traunspurger, 2002 ). Predation can have a strong (positive and negative) effect on meiofauna distribution in some freshwater systems (
Silver et al. , 2002
). Besides the effects on species composition, these interactions may also affect the diversity within species because in changing environments they promote the production of genetically variable offspring through sexual reproduction in facultative parthenogenetic species ( Yusa & Suzuki, 2002 ). The relationship between competition and investment in sexual reproduction was shown experimentally ( King & Serra, 1998 ) and theoretically ( Zhang & Jiang, 1995 ; Zhang & Hanski, 1998 ). Sex-ratio variation among families is known from several invertebrate taxa (
Werren et al. , 1981
;
Premoli et al. , 1996
) but has not yet generally been established for aquatic groups. However,
Ciros-Pérez et al. (2002)
demonstrated the relationship between competition and the investment in sexual reproduction for pelagic rotifers. They showed that competitive displacement between rotifer species was related to a higher investment in sexual reproduction by the displaced species.

The aim of our study was to analyse invertebrate communities of 11 alpine lakes. The nematode assemblages were identified to species and we examined their species richness, diversity, trophic composition and sex-ratio. The specific questions addressed in this study are: Are there general patterns in benthic and nematode community structures in alpine lakes? Are there relationships between benthic taxa with a similar food niche, indicating competitive or predator-prey interactions? Are higher species numbers (higher numbers of species interactions) correlated with an increased proportion of sexual reproduction within the community and within single species?

All alpine lakes were oligotrophic with a maximum depth of < 20 m and size ranging between 1 and 60 ha ( Table 1 ). The lakes receive their water through ice and small alpine streams, except for Froschhausersee which is spring-fed. The geology of most catchment areas is limestone.

Ten randomly sampled replicates were taken from the littoral of each lake between 4-7 June 2001. The uppermost 4 cm of the sediment layer was collected using a modified Kajak corer with an internal section of 5.31 cm 2 . All samples were fixed in formaldehyde (4% final concentration) and the organisms were extracted using the silica gel method (Ludox TM 50, mesh size: 35 µ m) modified from Pfannkuche and Thiel (1988) . All benthic taxa from each sample were counted and identified under a stereo-microscope (40 × magnification), after staining with Rose Bengal. Samples containing more than 200 nematodes were subsampled using a sample splitter. From each sample, 100 nematodes were selected randomly for identification, cleared in a glycerol-ethanol solution, stored in anhydrous glycerol, and prepared on microscope slides. Nematodes were identified to species level, following Andrássy (1984) and Loof (1999 , 2001 ). All other invertebrates were identified to coarse taxa. Sediment was sieved through a 63 µ m sieve to determine the clay content. Organic dry weight was determined by incubating the sediment at 105
◦
C ( > 4 h). The loss of ignition was measured after incubation at 490
◦
C ( > 6 h). Sediment carbon was assumed to be 50% of loss of ignition ( Hakanson & Jansson, 1983 ).

caption.paragraph:
Table 1. General characteristics of the studied alpine lakes. Altitude (above sea level), lake size (ha), % clay (particle size < 63 µm), and sediment organic carbon content (% dry weight), pH and O
2
content (mg/L) of the water.

tr.td: Lake Vilslache Traunsalpsee Vilsalpsee Lake Rehbach

subSection.paragraph:
Species richness, the Shannon-Wiener diversity index (H
ļ
; on ln basis), and species composition were determined per lake. The identified nematodes were then classified into five feeding types (plant, hyphal, bacterial and epistrate feeders, omnivorous nematodes), based on morphological characteristics of the buccal cavity and on the gut content (
Yeates et al. , 1993
; Traunspurger, 1997 ). Sexratios of the whole community and of those abundant species ( ̐ nine adults identified in ̐ three lakes) were analysed.

To examine for relationships between invertebrate abundance/biomass and abiotic parameters ( i.e ., organic carbon, lake size), and between invertebrates, correlation analyses were performed using Spearman rank coefficient. To estimate whether there was a negative interspecific relationship which could reflect competition within and among nematode feeding groups, we related their abundance and biomass. Further, the relationships between nematode species richness or specific population density and the nematode sex-ratio were examined.

The mean invertebrate abundance and biomass per lake, as well as of selected benthic groups is given in Table 2 . The composition of benthic organisms varied strongly between lakes ( Fig. 1 ). Benthic abundance tended to be greater with increasing organic carbon content (
rS
= 0.57; P = 0.06) but was not significantly related to lake size (
rS
= − 0.14; P = 0.69). The wide range of benthic abundances was due to the high variability in two taxa: tardigrades (varying by a factor of ca 50), and nematodes (varying by a factor of 45). Nematodes were the most abundant taxon in seven lakes, whereas tardigrades dominated in two lakes, and rotifers and crustaceans dominated only in one lake ( Table 2 ). Despite the low individual biomass of the nematodes, they reached the highest biomass of all invertebrates in six lakes, whereas crustaceans had the highest biomass in three lakes, and oligochaetes in two lakes. Benthic biomass was neither affected by lake size (
rS
= 0.24; P = 0.47) nor by organic carbon content (
rS
= 0.32; P = 0.34).

caption.paragraph:
Table 2. Abundance (individuals/cm
2
± SD) and biomass (mg dry weight/cm
2
± SD; in brackets) of benthic invertebrates, nematode species richness (N spec.) and nematode diversity (Shannon-Wiener Index H
ļ
).

subSection.paragraph: NEMATODE COMMUNITY COMPOSITION AND DIVERSITY

A total of 38 nematode families with 157 species were identified (Appendix 1). Species numbers ranged from 24 to 75 ( Table 2 ). The family Monhysteridae dominated in seven lakes (21-74%), whereas Rhabdolaimidae reached the greatest densities in Soiernsee (42%) and Ferchensee (44%). Tobrilidae dominated Lake Rehbach (29%) and Desmodoridae were most numerous in Lautersee (56%) ( Fig. 2 ).

All 11 lakes had only three species (
Eumonhystera filiformis
,
E. longicaudatula
and
Tripyla glomerans
) in common. A few species usually dominated the nematode communities ( Fig. 2 ), and six to 34 species contributed up to 90% of total density. A large proportion of species occurred in very small numbers only. Lake Vilslache and Lake Rehbach had the greatest diversity. In contrast, the lowest diversity was found in the lakes Wildensee, Lautersee, and Schmalsee ( Table 2 ).

caption.paragraph: Fig. 2. The relative abundance of the most numerous nematode species in 11 alpine lakes.

subSection.paragraph: Table 4 shows the relationships between abundance and biomass between trophic groups. The positive correlation between plant and hyphal as well as between bacterial and epistrate feeders could be due to similar food sources. Omnivorous nematode abundance and biomass were positively correlated with the abundance and biomass of all other feeding types (except for the biomass of epistrate feeders). Therefore, no evidence was found that nematode prey abundance and biomass were affected by the presence of omnivorous nematodes.

Most species found consisted of females (18-60%) and juveniles (38-81%). Relative male abundances varied between 0-9% among the lakes. The sex-ratio variation of abundant species is given in Table 5 . In most bacterialfeeding species, no males were found, while in all three omnivorous species at least in some lakes males were present. Overall sex-ratio increased in lakes with more coexisting species (
rS
= 0.69; P = 0.018) ( Fig. 4a ). The overall relative abundance of ‘parthenogenetic’ species (species without males in the investigated lakes) per lake did not decrease with an increasing number of coexisting species (
rS
= − 0.44; n.s.). However, within the feeding types, the expected relationship was found in bacterial feeders (
rS
= − 0.65; P = 0.029; Fig. 4b ), and was absent in omnivores (
rS
= − 0.21; n.s.) and epistrate feeders (
rS
= − 0.04; n.s.). In hyphal (
rS
= 0.80; P = 0.003) and plant feeders (
rS
= 0.64; P = 0.034), the relative abundance of ‘parthenogenetic’ species increased with the increasing number of coexisting species but abundance and species richness in these feeding types were low and the significance of these results is limited. Absolute nematode density had no effect on the sex-ratio (
rS
= − 0.04; P = 0.66). Therefore, it can be assumed that biotic interactions through increased species richness enhanced the production of males in facultative parthenogenetic and sexual species.

caption.paragraph: Table 5. Sex-ratio (minimum and maximum values) of abundant nematode species.
Fig. 4. The relationship between nematode species richness and (a) sex-ratio, and (b) the relative feeding type abundance of ‘parthenogenetic’ species.

subSection.paragraph: The investigated alpine lakes showed a general pattern in invertebrate community structure typical for oligotrophic freshwater habitats. The organic carbon content was the only abiotic factor influencing the benthic community composition. Several relationships between the invertebrate taxa were found. In benthic systems omnivory is widespread and links the dynamics of interacting species. This could prevent strong regulations through competition and predation. The higher sex-ratio and decreased rate of parthenogenesis in more speciose systems compared to less speciose systems could indicate that competition plays a role in natural nematode assemblages, but whether competition or predation shaped these alpine community structures cannot be answered without further experiments.

Many thanks go to Erna Gardner, Nico Michiels, Jenny Schmid-Araya and Hubert Spieth for helpful comments on earlier versions of the manuscript. We thank Nico Michiels for carrying heavy backpacks with sediment samples in the mountains. The study was supported by the German National Merit Foundation.
